metadata.title: Nano-diffusion bonding of Ti2AlNb to Ni-based superalloy

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Characterization
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/matchar
Nano-diffusion bonding of Ti2AlNb to Ni-based superalloy
H.S. Rena, X.Y. Rena, H.P. Xionga,⁎, W.W. Lia, S.J. Pangb, A.I. Ustinovc
aWelding and Plastic Forming Division, Beijing Institute of Aeronautical Materials, Beijing 100095, China bDepartment of Material Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China c E.O. Paton Electric Welding Institute of NAS of Ukraine, Kyiv 03680, Ukraine
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Ti2AlNb Diffusion bonding Nano-laminated foil Microstructure Mechanical properties
A B S T R A C T
Ti2AlNb alloys are one of the most promising structural materials with potential applications in aero-engines. Dissimilar joining of Ti2AlNb alloy to Ni-based superalloy was carried out with diffusion bonding method using Cu+Ti composite foil and Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil, respectively. Joint microstructures were analyzed with SEM, EPMA, XRD and TEM. The joint bonded with Cu+Ti composite foils presented shear strength of 114–167MPa at room temperature. For the joint bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated interlayer, Ti2Cu rather than TiCu reactive layer was visible and the sizes of phases were about 0.5–2 μm. A larger area of α-Ti phase was formed and the thickness of intermetallic compounds area decreased from the 35 μm to 18 μm. Raising bonding temperature could enhance the metallurgical bonding and improve the bonding quality. The joints bonded at 900 °C/20min/20MPa presented the maximum shear strength of 305MPa, increased about 82% compared with the Cu+Ti composite foil.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ti2AlNb alloy is a potential structural material for aerospace applications due to its low density, high creep and oxidation resistance at elevated temperatures [1]. Its long-term service temperature can be up to 700 °C–750 °C. Because of its high-temperature service potential as well as the weight reduction effect, Ti2AlNb alloy is inclined to be designed and adopted as one of the candidate materials for heat-resistance components in advanced aero-engines [2]. At present, Ni-based superallys are extensively used in aero-engine hot-section components. Then, the joining between Ti2AlNb alloy and Ni-based superalloy to produce dissimilar joints is of great interest to achieve the optimal material combination design.
A lot of studies on the joining of Ti2AlNb alloys to themselves have been reported and sound joints could be obtained [3–5]. However, the dissimilar joining between Ti2AlNb alloy and Ni-based superalloy is extremely difficult due to the following reasons. First, according to the TieNi binary alloy phase diagram [6], several kinds of TieNi intermetallics such as Ti2Ni, TiNi and TiNi3 could be formed. These phases lead to joint brittleness and further deteriorate the joint properties.
Secondly, the thermal expansion coefficient of Ni-based superalloy (~13.0×10−6 K−1) is substantially higher than that of the Ti2AlNb alloy (~9.1×10−6 K−1). The difference could influence the heat transfer during the welding and induce large residual thermal stress,
which would easily result in micro-cracks in the joint. Finally, chemical composition becomes a parameter that varies over a wide range across the joint. Hence, it is difficult to obtain a single liquidus isotherm defining the solid-liquid interface as it does in similar metals joining. Therefore, the joining of Ti2AlNb alloy to Ni-based superalloy is not only an extremely difficult technology problem but also a key scientific issue. It is a great importance to depress the formation of interfacial brittle phases and to ensure good metallurgical quality at the joining interface.
An attempt was made to braze Ti3Al-based alloy to Ni-based superalloy using Ti–Zr–Cu–Ni filler alloy. Within the brazed joint, continuous FeeTi and NieTi compounds were visible and they caused the formation of micro-cracks during cooling process. Consequently, the shear strength of the dissimilar joint was only 86MPa [7]. Laser method was also used to join Ti3Al-based alloy to Ni-based superalloy with a titanium interlayer, but the average tensile strength of the joint was only 177MPa [8]. The dissimilar brazing of Ti3Al-based alloy to a Nibased superalloy was also carried out by Ag-21Cu-25Pd (wt%) filler metal [9]. But obviously it is unpractical for the joint to be served at 750 °C. In general, the study on the dissimilar joining of Ti2AlNb alloy to nickel-based superalloy is still insufficient. And novel welding methods or materials should be innovated and explored.
Due to the small size effect, nanoscale materials exhibit distinctly properties different from bulk materials, including high specific surface
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matchar.2019.109813 Received 20 April 2019; Received in revised form 4 July 2019; Accepted 4 July 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: xionghp69@163.com, xionghuaping69@sina.cn (H.P. Xiong).
Materials Characterization 155 (2019) 109813
Available online 05 July 2019 1044-5803/ © 2019 Published by Elsevier Inc.
T
energy, high activity, low diffusion activation energy and high diffusion coefficients of atoms [10,11]. If nano-sized materials can be applied during welding process, their high specific surface energy and high activity could reduce energy demand and then decrease the welding temperature. Their high atoms diffusivity is beneficial to shorten dwell time. In the case of nano-sized welding materials application, the two base metals will be joined under relatively lower temperature and shorter time, which contributes to inhibiting the growth of intermetallic compounds.
In some previous studied, nano-sized multilayer was used as interlayer for the diffusion bonding of TiAl alloys. For example, alternated Ti (or Ni) and Al nanolayers were deposited onto the polished surface of the TiAl substrates via magnetron sputtering method, then Ti/Al [12,13] and Ni/Al [14] multilayers were obtained. During the diffusion bonding process, the alternated multi-nanolayers were beneficial to activate the joining process and decrease the necessary joining temperature. The energy generated by the exothermic reaction between the nanolayers would assist the diffusion behavior and enhance the bonding efficiency. As reported, the utilization of these multilayers decreased the bonding temperature and pressure, and also shortened the bonding time. The strength of the bonded TiAl joints reached 314MPa [14]. It will be more significant if nano-sized multilayer could be used in the dissimilar joining between different materials.
The application of nanoscale multilayer foils during diffusion bonding process provides new methods and technologies to solve joining problems. However, the corresponding research in this field is far insufficient. Up to now, only Ti/Al and Ni/Al system multilayer foils were found in the joining experiments of TiAl alloys. Different from the conventional joining methods, as nanoscale materials are used novel phenomena and phases might occur [15]. This will offer more perspectives on welding and materials study to researchers. Therefore, more understanding to the new bonding method is not only connected with sound joint properties but also a key scientific issue to the new field.
In the present study, Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil was used as interlayer during the diffusion bonding of Ti–24Al–15Nb–1Mo (at.%) alloy to Ni-based superalloy (GH536). The microstructure and mechanical properties of the joints were investigated. The purpose of this work is to offer new understanding to the specific metallurgical behavior during the nano-bonding process. Furthermore, conventional Cu+Ti composite interlayer were also used for comparison to reveal the difference between them and explore the joining mechanism.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental procedures
sections.text:
The Ti2AlNb-based alloy with a nominal composition of Ti-24Al15Nb-1Mo (at.%) is used in this experiment. It is composed of lath α2Ti3Al, fine lamellar O-Ti2AlNb and the β/B2 matrix. The lamellar OTi2AlNb phase was precipitated from the β/B2 matrix during cooling process [16]. This alloy was prepared by the following steps: vacuumconsumable electrode arc melting, breaking down in the β/B2 phase fields, forging and rolling in the α2+ B2 phase field, and heat treating at 980 °C for 1 h followed by cooling in air. The other base material to be joined in this experiment is GH536 superalloy with the chemical composition given in Table 1. This Ni-based superalloy presents a longterm service temperature of 900 °C.
The Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil (Fig. 1a) was fabricated through electron beam physical vapor deposition (EB-PVD) method. The manufacture process was described in Ref. [17]. The total thickness of this
foil was about 30 μm. Its microstructure was observed by a scanning electron microscope (Nova NanoSEM 450). Its phase composition was analyzed through X-ray diffraction (XRD) method. Prior to bonding, the joined samples and Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil were ultrasonically cleaned in acetone, and then the nano-laminated foil was sandwiched between the two base metals. The joined couple was heated to a bonding temperature varying from 800 °C to 980 °C, with a constant bonding time of 20min and a fixed pressure of 20MPa. During the bonding experiment the vacuum was kept between 7×10−3 Pa and 8×10−4 Pa and the heating rate was 10 °C/min. After the brazing experiment, to decrease the residual thermal stress the brazed joint was cooled down to 500 °C with a low cooling rate of 4.5 °C/min and then furnace-cooled naturally to room temperature.
For the sake of contrast, pure titanium foil and copper foil were used as composite interlayer (Fig. 1b). Both of the thickness of titanium foil and copper foil were 20 μm. In order to remove oxide layers, the titanium foil was cleaned in an aqueous HF solution (2%), while the copper foil in an aqueous HNO3 solution (5%). Then both foils were rinsed with water and ethanol in sequence. The joint structure was set in the form of Ti2AlNb/Ti/Cu/GH536.
After diffusion bonding experiment, the joint microstructures were examined using a scanning electron microscope (JXA-8100) equipped with an electron probe micro-analyzer (EPMA). An X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectrometer with CueK radiation (D/max-RB) was carried out to identify the reaction phases within the joint. Furthermore, the morphological structure of the reaction phases was also examined using transmission electron microscopy (JEM-2010). The preparation steps of TEM samples were as follows: A cylinder sample with a diameter of 5mm was cut from the Ti3Al/GH536 joint and the bonded interface should be in the centre of the sample. Next, slice samples with a thickness of 200 μm were cut from the cylinder sample and then ground to the thickness of 30 μm. Finally, the ground slice samples were further prepared by ion thinning instrument.
The mechanical characterization was performed by shear strength at room temperature. According to the test standard of GB/T74132005, the shear test was carried out using an electronic universal materials testing machine (INSTRON5887) with a loading rate of 0.0084mm·s−1. Details of the joint specimen and the illustration of the shear test were shown in Fig. 2. The reported average strength was obtained from at least three joint specimens.

sections.heading: 3.1. Diffusion bonding with Cu+Ti composite interlayer
3.1.1. Microstructure of Ti2AlNb/Cu+Ti/GH536 joints
sections.text:
Fig. 3 presents the backscattered electron images of Ti2AlNb/GH536 joints bonded with Cu+Ti composite interlayer. The EPMA analysis results for the typical microzones in these joints are displayed in Table 2. For the joint bonded at 850 °C, both Ti and Cu foils were residual. α-Ti (“1”) and α-Cu (“6”) layers were detected as shown in Fig. 3a. Ti2Cu phase was formed in microzones “2” and “3”. According to the TieCu binary phase diagram [6], the lowest eutectic temperature is about 875 °C. Hence, liquid phase should not appear during the bonding process at 850 °C. And the joint microstructure was formed through atoms inter-diffusion and solid state phase transformation. Cu atoms diffused into Ti foil and formed α-Ti solid solution dissolved with Cu. As the diffusion continued, saturated α-Ti solid solution was formed. When α-Ti solid solution was supersaturated, Ti2Cu could be
nucleated at the interface between the α-Ti solid solution and α-Cu layer [18].
In the centre of the joint, a TiCu reactive layer (microzone “4”) with a thickness of about 8 μm is visible. Besides, a thin Cu3Ti reactive layer (microzone “5”) is found between the layers of TiCu and α-Cu. The formation process of Cu3Ti reactive layer (microzone “5”) is similar to the Ti2Cu phase in microzone “3”.
Within the joint bonded at 900 °C (Fig. 3b), no α-Ti or α-Cu layers are retained and the grey phases in microzones “7” and “8” are identified as Ti2Cu. More elements Al and Nb are detected in these areas than that in microzone “1” (Fig. 3a), inferring that Ti2AlNb substrate took part in the interface reaction. Besides, discrete α-Ti (“9”) is visible in the joint center. The reaction layer in microzone “10” is also Ti2Cu phase.
In addition, similar to the joint in Fig. 3a, a TiCu reaction layer with a thickness of about 10 μm is also found in Fig. 3b. Based on the previous results, TiCu phase showed a lower formation enthalpy than those of other TieCu compounds, and it might be the most stable TieCu compound [19]. Hence, it is not strange to observe that TiCu reaction layers became thicker than other layers in both of the joints. Concerning microzone “12”, owning to more Ni atoms diffused into the bonded area, ternary τ1-CuTiNi phase formed. In microzone “13”, (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components phase is visible and this area should be the diffusion effect zone of GH536 substrate. Besides, micro-crack is observed between this zone and τ1-CuTiNi phase. As shown in Table 2, there is an abrupt change in compositions between microzone “13” and microzones “11, 12”. The difference in thermal expansion coefficient would cause residual thermal stress after bonding experiment. Considering the weak link within the joint, is easy to induce micro-cracks.
Generally speaking, the joint was characterized with TieCu phases. For the joint bonded at 950 °C (Fig. 3c), more Ti2AlNb base metal participated in the interface reaction and the joint was dominated by αTi dissolved with Al, Nb, Cu and Ni. TieNi and TieCu reaction layers were formed in the joint centre. When the bonding temperature was further increased to 980 °C (Fig. 3d), even continuous crack was induced within the joint central area. Due to the relatively higher bonding temperature, more Ni element from GH536 took part in the reaction with Ti foil. The EPMA analysis results indicate that phases Ti2Ni and TiNi were formed in the joint centre, increased the joint brittleness. Residual thermal stress caused by the difference in thermal expansion coefficient leaded to the continuous crack.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Mechanical properties of Ti2AlNb/Cu+Ti/GH536 joints
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the room-temperature shear strengths of the Ti2AlNb/ GH536 joints as a function of bonding temperature. With the raising of bonding temperature, the joints shear strength firstly increase and then decrease. The bonding temperature of 900 °C offers a shear strength of 167MPa. In general, the joints bonded with composite Cu+Ti interlayer present a lower strength.
Fig. 5 displays the cross-section of the joints after shear test. As shown in Fig. 5a, the joint failed along the TiCu layer and cracks also occurred at the interface between TiCu layer and phases of αTi+ Ti2Cu. For the joint bonded at 900 °C (Fig. 5b), it mainly fractured at phases of TiCu and τ1-CuTiNi. Meanwhile, some discontinuous cracks are observed within the α-Ti phase. The joint in Fig. 5c fractured at the interface between Ti(Cu, Ni) phase and the diffusion effect zone of GH536 substrate. In addition, the failure area of the joint bonded at 980 °C (Fig. 5d) was corresponded to the continuous cracks in Fig. 3d.
For the joint bonded at 850 °C (Fig. 3a), because of the low strength, the existence of α-Cu layer is detrimental to the joint properties. In Fig. 3b, no α-Cu layer was retained and discrete α-Ti and Ti2Cu was formed. It is beneficial to improve the joint mechanical properties. Thus the joint strength was increased compared to the joint in Fig. 3a. However, these detects as shown in Fig. 3, which were resulted from residual thermal stress, limited the joint strength.
Furthermore, as mentioned above the thicknesses of the TiCu layers are about 8–10 μm and TiCu phase could present a high hardness value of 783 HV [20]. Besides, in a previous study [21], the Pugh's ratio of G/ B was proposed to evaluate brittle and ductile behavior of materials, where the G is the shear modulus and B is the bulk modulus of materials. The ductile materials should meet G/B < 0.57, otherwise the materials are considered to be brittle. According to the first principles investigation to TieCu intermetallics [19], the Pugh's ratio of TiCu was 0.61 (> 0.57). It was larger than that of Ti2Cu (0.55), Cu3Ti (0.46), α-Ti (0.40) and α-Cu (0.34), indicating the TiCu intermetallic presented a strong brittleness tendency. As a result, the TiCu layer embrittled the joint and deteriorated the joint strength. Thus both the joints in Fig. 3a
and b displayed relatively low shear strengths.

sections.heading: 3.2. Diffusion bonding with Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil
3.2.1. Microstructure of Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil
sections.text:
Fig. 6a shows the microstructure of Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil. It is consisted of laminated Ti and Cu nano-layers. The configuration and thickness of nanolayers were homogenous. The measurement results indicate that the thickness of single Ti and Cu nano-layer is about 170 nm and 80 nm, respectively. A previous study reported that intermetallic phases were found on interlayer boundaries within Ti/Al and Ti/Cu multilayers produced via vacuum-arc evaporation of pure metal [22]. Therefore, X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out in order to determine the phase constitution of the foil. From the XRD pattern in Fig. 6b, the nano-laminated foil is composed not only by the pure Ti and Cu metals but also by Ti2Cu phase. However, the peaks in the XRD pattern corresponded to Ti2Cu phase are not strong, illustrating the formation of this phase was limited and did not propagate along the full thickness of nano-layers.
Adams [15] proposed that atomically sharp interfaces are rarely found within the multilayer materials. More often, there is a ~0.1- 10 nm thick layer of mixed reactants at each interface. Hence, it is deduced that atoms interdiffusion between nano-layers occurred during the EB-PVD deposition process and Ti2Cu phase was formed at the interface between nano-layers. It might be related to the very high aspect ratio of the nanostructure, the large interlayer surfaces and high mobility of atoms within the Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Microstructure of Ti2AlNb/Cu/Ti/GH536 joints
sections.text:
Fig. 7 presents the backscattered electron images of Ti2AlNb/GH536 joints bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil. With the increase of the bonding temperature, the joints microstructure is characterized with different morphologies. Under the bonding temperature of 800 °C
(Fig. 7a), a sound bonding interface between Ti2AlNb parent metal and Cu/Ti foil was obtained. However, cracks were formed between the joint and GH536 superalloy. Besides, some black phases are visible but the original Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil disappears.
Increasing the bonding temperature within limits was beneficial to improve the joint quality. At the bonding temperature of 850 °C, Ti2AlNb/GH536 joint without defects was obtained as shown in Fig. 7b. According to the EPMA analysis results in Table 3, Ti2Cu (“1” in Fig. 7b) dissolved with little element Ni is formed in the central of the joint. Adjacent to the Ti2AlNb substrate, little discrete α-Ti (“2” in Fig. 7b) is detected. Due to the diffusion effect, Ti(Cu,Ni) phase is visible in microzone “3” (Fig. 7b). Generally speaking, both of the joints in Fig. 7a and b are dominated by Ti2Cu phase deduced from the reaction between the Ti and Cu nanolayers (Table 3).
At the bonding temperature of 900 °C, a joint microstructure with multiple layer structure was achieved as shown in Fig. 7c. The joint could be divided into four zones. For the zone I, the grey phase in microzone “4” is α-Ti phase dissolved with Al and Nb. The black phases in microzone “5” are identified as the eutectoid microstructure of α-Ti and Ti2Cu. The phases of α-Ti and Ti2Cu were detected through XRD analysis (Fig. 8) on the fractured surface at the joint.
The phase in zone II with a thickness of 9 μm is Ti2Cu (microzone “6”). Compared with the joint in Fig. 7b (28 μm), the thickness of Ti2Cu zone is obviously decreased. On the contrary, the grey white phases in zone III are increased. Similar to microzone “3”, the phase in microzones “7” and “8” is identified as Ti(Cu, Ni). Due to the peaks corresponding to phases Ti2Ni and TiNi was detected on the XRD pattern (Fig. 8), Ti2Ni and TiNi might be formed in zone III. In addition, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) results in Fig. 9 further confirmed the presence of phases Ti2Ni (fcc) and Ti2Cu (tetragonal primitive). And the sizes of these phases are about 0.5–2 μm. Besides, (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components phase was formed in microzone “9”.
For the joint bonded at 920 °C (Fig. 7d), it presents a similar microstructure to the joint in Fig. 7c. The typical interfacial
microstructure within the bonded Ti2AlNb/GH536 joint from Ti2AlNb side to GH536 side can be described as the follows: Ti2AlNb substrate/ α-Ti dissolved with Al+ Ti2Cu/Ti2Cu/Ti(Cu, Ni)/(Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multicomponents/ GH536 substrate.
However, when bonded at 950 °C (Fig. 7e), micro-cracks are visible
between Ti(Cu,Ni) phase and (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components phase. Particularly, when the bonding temperature is increased to 980 °C, the joint microstructure is significantly different from that in Fig. 7c. The EPMA analysis results indicate that a reaction area (microzone “10”) adjacent to Ti2AlNb substrate with a thickness of 20 μm is identified as
O-Ti2AlNb dissolved with Cu and Ni. Besides, continuous Ti2Ni and TiNi reaction layers dissolved with Cu were formed in microzones “11” and “12”, respectively. Micro-cracks are observed within the Ti2Ni layer and (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components phase.
For the typical joint (Fig. 3a) bonded with Cu+Ti interlayer, it mainly consists of Ti2Cu, TiCu and τ1-CuTiNi. In contrast, a larger area of α-Ti phase was formed in the typical joint (Fig. 7c) bonded with Cu/ Ti nano-laminated foil. And the thickness of compounds area decreased to 18 μm from the 35 μm corresponded to Cu+Ti composite interlayer. Furthermore, the grains have been refined as illustrated in Fig. 9. These are beneficial to decrease the joint brittleness and improve the joint strength.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Microstructure evolution mechanism of Ti2AlNb/Cu/Ti/GH536 joints
sections.text:
Undoubtedly, the joint microstructure strongly affects the mechanical performance of the brazed joints. It is quite necessary to reveal the formation mechanism of interfacial microstructure and reaction behaviors between different elements during bonding process. Therefore,
Table 3 EPMA analysis results for the microzones in Fig. 7, at.%.
Microzones Ti Al Nb Ni Cu Mo Fe Cr Deduced phases
1 66.93 / / 3.70 28.93 / 0.44 / Ti2Cu 2 88.99 0.54 / 0.54 9.92 / / / α-Ti dissolved with Cu 3 55.17 / / 16.66 23.58 / 2.88 1.71 Ti(Cu,Ni) 4 72.11 8.96 13.59 0.60 4.73 / / / α-Ti dissolved with Al and Nb 5 69.33 12.65 2.52 0.40 15.10 / / / α-Ti dissolved with Al+Ti2Cu 6 66.61 1.27 0.39 1.35 30.38 / / / Ti2Cu 7 52.05 0.70 / 13.07 30.58 / 2.43 1.18 Ti(Cu,Ni) 8 51.68 / / 19.37 16.61 / 8.63 3.04 9 10.35 / / 31.02 / 8.56 16.84 33.23 (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components phase 10 57.74 16.05 14.20 4.35 4.34 / 1.34 1.53 O-Ti2AlNb(Ni,Cu) 11 58.36 7.76 1.96 19.98 7.97 / 3.06 0.95 Ti2Ni(Cu) 12 41.90 5.19 1.11 34.65 5.05 1.93 7.48 2.68 TiNi(Cu)
the distribution of elements within the joint in Fig. 7c was analyzed as shown in Fig. 10. For element Cu (Fig. 10a), it was enriched in zone II (Fig. 7c) for the presence of phase Ti2Cu. Moreover, Cu atoms diffused into the Ti2AlNb substrate, as a result Ti2Cu particle precipitated within the α-Ti phase (zone I in Fig. 7c). However, as Fig. 10a presented little Cu atoms were detected within the GH536 substrate, even in the zone IV (Fig. 7c).
On the basis of ref. [23], the dissolution enthalpy of element Ti in melts of Cu was much lower than that of Ni in Cu (Table 4), indicating the strong affinity of Cu with Ti. Moreover, diffusion coefficient (D0) and activation energy (Q) of Cu in Ti at 775 °C–1050 °C are D0= 2.7× 10−5 m2/s and Q=255.5 kJ/mol, whereas those of Cu in Ni at 900 °C–1500 °C are D0=5.7× 10−5 m2/s and Q=241.0 kJ/mol, respectively [24]. Hence, the diffusion velocities (D) of Cu in Ti and Ni at 900 °C are DCu-Ti = 1.06×10−15 m2/s and DCuNi= 1.13× 10−16 m2/s, respectively, calculated through Arrhenius
equation (D=D0 exp (− Q
RT )). Distinctly, Cu atoms can diffuse faster in Ti than in Ni. To some extent, these calculated results could explain why more Cu atoms diffused towards Ti2AlNb substrate during the bonding process (Fig. 10a).
Besides, based on Figs. 7 and 10 the interface between zone III and IV (Fig. 7c) is deduced to be the original interface. As shown in Fig. 10c, the diffusion depth thickness of element Ni towards the joint is about 13 μm. Nevertheless, for the joint bonded with conventional Cu+Ti interlayer, the diffusion depth thickness of Ni towards the joint is only 3 μm (Fig. 3b). This is due to the high diffusivity and reactivity of Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil. The high aspect ratio of the nanostructure and the large interfaces leaded to a high mobility of Ni atoms. Owing to the dilutive effect of element Ni, both the concentrations of Ti and Cu in zone III were lower than that in zone II as presented in Fig. 10c. Therefore, Ti(Cu, Ni) phase rather than TiCu reaction layer was detected.
Moreover, it should be noted that little elements Al and Nb diffused into the joint (Fig. 10d and e). As Table 4 indicated, the affinities of Al and Nb with Ti are stronger than that with Cu. Therefore, driving force of diffusion towards the joint is small.
In order to describe the bonding process intuitively, a simplified schematic diagram of the microstructure evolution was proposed in Fig. 11. Fig. 11a showed the schematic diagram of the sample assembly. Because of the high specific surface energy and high activity, the
reaction between the Ti and Cu nanolayers could happen easily. During the heating process, the energy from the furnace activated this reaction within the Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil and then more Ti2Cu phase was formed (Fig. 11b). Meanwhile, the Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil also reacted with Ti2AlNb substrate and GH536 base metal. Owning to the diffusion of elements Ti and Ni into the joint, particles of α-Ti phase was visible adjacent to Ti2AlNb substrate. Moreover, Ti(Cu,Ni) phase was detected as shown in Fig. 11b.
With the further increase of bonding temperature, the inter-diffusion between Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil and base metals was intensified (Fig. 11c). Cu atoms diffused into Ti2AlNb substrate, Ti2Cu particles and α-Ti phase were formed at the interface adjacent to Ti2AlNb substrate. In the meantime, with the entrance of more and more Ni atoms, the
Ti2Cu phase within the joint transformed into Ti(Cu, Ni). As a result, the Ti2Cu phase area was decreased obviously. On the other hand, Ti atoms also diffused into GH536 base metal to some extent, leading to the formation of (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components phase.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Mechanical properties of Ti2AlNb/Cu/Ti/GH536 joints
sections.text:
Fig. 12 displays the room-temperature shear strengths of the Ti2AlNb/GH536 joints as a function of bonding temperature. The joint bonded at 800 °C presents a low strength of only 66MPa. With the raising of bonding temperature, the joint strength increase obviously. In particular, under the bonding temperature of 900 °C the average joint strength reaches the maximum value of 305MPa. However, further increase of bonding temperature results in the joint strength decrease due to the presence of some defects (Fig. 7e and f).
As Fig. 7 illustrated, under the bonding temperature of 800 °C (Fig. 7a), cracks are formed between the joint and GH536 superalloy. Hence, the joint shows a low shear strength. With the increase of bonding temperature, the joint microstructure is improved (Fig. 7b) and defects are absent. It is beneficial to increase the joint strength. When bonded at 900 °C (Fig. 7c), the thickness of Ti2Cu zone (II) is reduced but α-Ti area increase, which is believed to decrease the joint brittleness. On the contrary, for the joint obtained at 980 °C (Fig. 7f), more Ni atoms diffused into the joint from the GH536 base metal and reacted with Ti2Cu, leading to the formation of continuous Ti2Ni and TiNi reaction layers. Consequently, the joint brittleness remarkably increased. Considering the difference in thermal expansion coefficient between the Ti2AlNb substrate and GH536 base metal, it is not strange to observe continuous micro-cracks within the joint.
In order to identify the fracture mechanism of the Ti2AlNb/GH536 joints, the specimens after shear tests were inspected. As shown in Fig. 13a, the joint mainly fractured in zone “2”. The composition analysis results at the fractured surface in Table 5 indicate that the phase in zones “1” and “3” is Ti2Cu. And the phase in zone “2” is identified as Ti (Ni,Fe,Cr) multi-components phase. Fig. 13b presents the cross section of the fracture surface and the crack propagation path is visible. The
joint fractured at the interface between Ti(Cu,Ni) and (Ni,Cr,Fe,Ti) multi-components. It is not strange that Ti(Ni,Fe,Cr) multi-components phase is detected in zone “2” (Fig. 13a).
In comparison with the Ti2AlNb/GH536 joints bonded with Cu+Ti interlayer, Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil displays its advantage. Firstly, a larger area of α-Ti phase was formed in the typical joint bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil, different from the joint bonded with Cu+Ti interlayer that mainly consists of Ti2Cu, TiCu and τ1-CuTiNi. And the thickness of compounds area decrease to 18 μm from the 35 μm corresponded to Cu+Ti composite interlayer, beneficial to improve joint strengths [2].
In addition, the grains have been refined and Ti2Cu phase with micrometer size rather than TiCu reactive layer with thickness of 8–10 μm was formed within the joint bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil. In a previous report about electron beam welding of Ti/Cu, the author proposed that the ductility and performance of joint were improved when the brittle TiCu phase was transformed into Ti2Cu [25]. Actually, the Ti2Cu phase gave a lower microhardness value (530 HV [26]) than TiCu (783 HV [20]). And the Pugh's ratio of Ti2Cu (0.55) was also lower than TiCu phase (0.61), even lower than the critical Pugh's ratio (> 0.57) [21]. These data fully indicate that Ti2Cu presents a much lower brittleness than the TiCu phase, which is beneficial to improve the joint properties. Finally, the joint strength obtained from Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil reaches 305MPa, increased about 82% compared with Cu+Ti interlayer. And because of the exothermic reaction between the Cu and Ti nanolayers, the optimal bonding strength is achieved at the bonding temperature of 900 °C.
In previous studies, conventional metal foils were used as interlayers to investigate the diffusion bonding of Ti2AlNb and Ni-based superalloy. For instance, Qian et al. conducted the bonding of Ti–20Al–25Nb (at.%) to In718 superalloy by inserting metal foils of Nb+Ni as interlayer [27]. Ni3Nb and Ni6Nb7 reactive layers were formed and micropores were visible in both Ti2AlNb/Nb and Ni/In718 interfaces. Moreover, conventional Ni foil and a TiNiNb alloy foil were also used as interlayers for the diffusion bonding of Ti2AlNb and GH536 superalloy [28]. The joints presented shear strengths of about 210MPa at the bonding temperature of 980 °C, obviously lower than the joint bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil. Hence, it can be concluded that it is possible to decrease the temperature of the Ti2AlNb/GH536 diffusion bonding experiments and still achieve good joints through using Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: (1) In the Ti2AlNb/GH536 joints bonded with Cu+Ti composite interlayer, continuous TiCu reactive layer with thickness of 8–10 μm was formed and the maximum shear strength of the joints was 167MPa. (2) The Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil was composed of α-Ti, α-Cu and Ti2Cu phase. The Ti2Cu phase was formed at the interface between nano-layers due to the very high aspect ratio of the nanostructure and high mobility of atoms. (3) For the joint bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil, a large area of α-Ti phase was formed, Ti2Cu rather than TiCu reactive layer was visible and phases were in size of micron level. The thickness of compounds area decreased to 18 μm from the 35 μm, beneficial to improve joint properties. Joint shear strength reached 305MPa, obviously higher than that bonded with Cu+Ti composite interlayer. In the meantime the optimal bonding temperature decreased to 900 °C. (4) Compared with conventional interlayers, nano-laminated materials with high activity showed a potential for some dissimilar and difficult materials. Novel phenomena and scientific laws was deserved to be explored and studied.

referenceMentions.context: Ti2AlNb alloy is a potential structural material for aerospace applications due to its low density, high creep and oxidation resistance at elevated temperatures [1].

Because of its high-temperature service potential as well as the weight reduction effect, Ti2AlNb alloy is inclined to be designed and adopted as one of the candidate materials for heat-resistance components in advanced aero-engines [2].

metadata.abstractText: Ti2AlNb alloys are one of the most promising structural materials with potential applications in aero-engines. Dissimilar joining of Ti2AlNb alloy to Ni-based superalloy was carried out with diffusion bonding method using Cu+Ti composite foil and Cu/Ti nano-laminated foil, respectively. Joint microstructures were analyzed with SEM, EPMA, XRD and TEM. The joint bonded with Cu+Ti composite foils presented shear strength of 114–167MPa at room temperature. For the joint bonded with Cu/Ti nano-laminated interlayer, Ti2Cu rather than TiCu reactive layer was visible and the sizes of phases were about 0.5–2 μm. A larger area of α-Ti phase was formed and the thickness of intermetallic compounds area decreased from the 35 μm to 18 μm. Raising bonding temperature could enhance the metallurgical bonding and improve the bonding quality. The joints bonded at 900 °C/20min/20MPa presented the maximum shear strength of 305MPa, increased about 82% compared with the Cu+Ti composite foil.
